title: EverWatt Energy Efficiency Certification - For Hospitality Engineers
subtitle: Certification for energy efficiency in hotels and resorts
description: Validate your expertise in identifying and implementing energy efficiency measures for hotels and resorts. This certification covers guest room HVAC, kitchens, laundry, pools/spas, and 24/7 operations.

questions.question: In hotels, what percentage of total energy is typically consumed by HVAC systems?
questions.explanation: HVAC systems typically consume 40-55% of total energy in hotels. This includes guest room HVAC (PTAC units), common area HVAC, and kitchen ventilation.

questions.question: A hotel has 200 guest rooms with PTAC units. The units run continuously. What efficiency opportunity exists?
questions.scenario: A hotel has 200 guest rooms, each with a PTAC (Packaged Terminal Air Conditioner) unit. The units run continuously, even when rooms are unoccupied. Guests often leave windows open while units run.

options.text: Install occupancy-based controls and guest education on proper operation

questions.explanation: Installing occupancy-based controls (sensors, keycard switches) can reduce guest room HVAC energy by 20-40%. Guest education on proper operation (closing windows, using controls) can provide additional savings. This is typically more cost-effective than replacing all units or installing central systems.

questions.question: A hotel has a pool that operates year-round. The pool pump runs 24/7. What energy efficiency opportunity exists?

options.text: Install a VFD and scheduling controls to reduce runtime

questions.explanation: All measures are valuable. Installing a VFD and scheduling controls can reduce pump energy by 50-70%. Pool covers can reduce heating energy by 20-40%. A combination of measures provides the best results.

questions.question: What is the typical priority order for energy efficiency measures in hotels?

options.text: Guest Room HVAC, Common Area HVAC, Kitchen/Laundry, Lighting, Pools/Spas
Lighting, HVAC, Building Envelope, Plug Loads
Building Envelope, HVAC, Lighting, Plug Loads
Plug Loads, Lighting, HVAC, Building Envelope

questions.explanation: For hotels, Guest Room HVAC is typically Very High priority (largest single end use). Common Area HVAC is High priority. Kitchen/Laundry is High priority. Lighting is High priority. Pools/Spas are Medium-High priority.
